chapters.gist: The Attraction Effect and Information visualization
chapters.headline: We want to talk about the paper on attraction effect and information visualization

chapters.summary: The map lineups idea again, and I think that's an honorable mention. What they did was basically try to apply this technique to maps. One of the things they looked at is how, in maps, the size of a spatial region is going to be important. Nice.
chapters.headline: Effect of spatial structure on graphical inference by Roger becom or Beecham

chapters.summary: On Wednesday, there was a first session on textual data. I want to talk about our paper that was about textile, a new piece of software that we developed. The title is an interactive visualization tool for seamless exploratory analysis of structured data and a structured text. It's very exciting, practical work.
chapters.headline: On Wednesday, there was a first session on textual data

chapters.summary: A group from Tufts University and WPI has created a patient centered visualization for effective prostate cancer health risk. It's a very rare example of applying visualization to our very important practical application.
chapters.gist: Applying visualization to prostate cancer health risk
chapters.headline: The first paper is about a system called proact for prostate cancer visualization

chapters.summary: Visual weight space exploration for multi criteria decision making. Created by the folks from VRV in Vienna. Uses sentenced widgets to show you how much space you have and where your solution improves or not.
chapters.headline: Visual weight space exploration for multi criteria decision making

chapters.summary: The conference has three tracks, and one is called scientific visualization. Since 2006, the number of papers, number of citations to the scientific visualization part has slowly been decreasing. The old guard is feeling a bit slighted, and they're trying to figure out what to do.
chapters.headline: The vis conference has three tracks, and one is called scientific visualization

chapters.summary: SCIVIS is doing the worst in diversity in scientific visualization. There is just no diversity in cybizing. I think what we're going to see next year is to see at least a panel or something on diversity.
chapters.gist: The Diversity in Scientific visualization panel
chapters.headline: Panel on diversity in scientific visualization at Baltimore conference was interesting

chapters.summary: Last session we want to talk about from Wednesday is the evaluation session. First paper is evaluating the impact of beaning to the scalar field by lace Padilla. They basically questioned expressiveness for this particular case. Maybe there's actually some things that are outside of our current set of guidelines that are actually working.
chapters.gist: The Impact of Beaning on Data Science
chapters.headline: Last session we want to talk about from Wednesday is the evaluation session

chapters.summary: The paper addressed an experimental question that comes from talking a lot with practitioners. This kind of idea of trying to understand why certain practitioners do something in a certain way and translate that in a controlled experiment is a fantastic idea. It's a very initial tiny step, but it's a step in the right direction.
chapters.headline: This paper addresses experimental question that comes from talking a lot with practitioners

chapters.summary: The elicitation interview technique captures people's experiences of data representations. People tend to inject their personal stories when they are extracting information from graphs. I think we need to understand more how people are thinking when they use visualizations.
chapters.gist: The Quantitative Analysis of Data Visualizations
chapters.headline: Jessica: I think we need to understand more how people think when using visualizations

chapters.summary: We had a whole session on storytelling and presentations. It was a lot of figuring out what are the pain points in the process of creating narrative visualizations. One paper looked at ways that you could bridge between tools so that you can move back and forth.
chapters.gist: The Future of Storytelling and Presentations
chapters.headline: We had a whole session on storytelling and presentations on Thursday

chapters.summary: Data driven guides paper. Supporting expressive design for information graphics by Nam Wook Kim, Eston Schweickart, Zhicheng Liu Mira Dontcheva Wilmot Li, Jovan Popovic, and Hanspeter Pfister. I wasn't very excited about the presentation.
chapters.gist: Data driven guides: expressive design for information graphics
chapters.headline: Data driven guides allows you to draw information graphics based on data

chapters.summary: Another paper in the same session that got a lot of attention was color gorko creating discriminable and preferable color palettes for information visualization. The tool allows you to control the degree to which discriminability between the different shades in your color palette and the preferability of the color.
chapters.gist: Color Gorko: Creating discriminable and preferable color pal
chapters.headline: Color gorko creates discriminable and preferable color palettes for information visualization

chapters.summary: The surprise technique is called surprise Bayesian waiting for the biasing thematic maps. The idea is that a lot of times with things like choropleth maps, you try to graph some variable, some thematic variables. This work really is the total antidote to that, hopefully.
chapters.headline: Jessica: Surprise Bayesian waiting for the biasing thematic maps is interesting

chapters.summary: A focus on improving methods, but with a unique, maybe emphasis on statistics this year. This is informed by kind of like the replication crisis in psychology and other fields. There was a whole session on visualizing machine learning models. I think that's a very positive trend.
chapters.headline: There was a unique emphasis on statistics this year at vast

chapters.summary: There seems to be more introspection on panels this year than in previous years. It's a sign of maybe field maturity. When you start turning inward.
chapters.headline: There seems to be more introspection this year at the conference

chapters.summary: There are four parties now that are organized independently from the conference. All happen to be in the same place, which is an irish pub. I think that really helps the conference become more of a social thing. We can always improve, of course.
chapters.headline: There are four parties now that are organized independently from the conference

chapters.summary: Okay, shall we wrap it up? Good. That was fun, as usual. Thank you for devoting some of your time for the show. Have a good trip back. Bye bye.
chapters.headline: Okay, shall we wrap it up? Good. Thanks. That was fun, as usual

chapters.summary: Before you leave, we have a request if you can spend a couple of minutes reading us on iTunes. Here's also some information on the many ways you can get news directly from us. We love to get in touch with our listeners, especially if you want to suggest a way to improve the show.
chapters.headline: Before you leave, we have a request if you can spend a couple of minutes reading us on iTunes

episode_metadata.episode_title: Highlights from IEEE VIS'16 with Jessica Hullman and Robert Kosara
